rules.summary: Employer cannot delay salary without notice.
conditions: Wages must be paid by the 7th-10th of the following month (Payment of Wages Act).
exceptions: Companies with < 1,000 employees can pay by the 7th; others by the 10th.
Written agreement for different cycle (rare exceptions).
rules.simple_explanation: Your employer must pay your salary on time, usually by the 7th or 10th of the month. They cannot simply delay it without a valid reason and prior notice.
rules.detailed_explanation: Under the Payment of Wages Act, 1936, employers are legally bound to pay wages on time. Deductions or delays are only permitted for specific reasons like authorized absence, and must be communicated.
examples: Boss says 'money is tight' and holds salary for 2 months.
Salary is consistently paid on the 20th without agreement.
rules.what_to_say: I understand the situation, but my financial commitments rely on my salary being paid by the 7th as per the Payment of Wages Act. Please confirm when it will be credited.

rules.summary: Unpaid overtime is generally not allowed for eligible employees.
conditions: Work beyond 9 hours/day or 48 hours/week usually requires 2x pay (Factories Act/Shops Act).
Applies to 'workmen' or non-managerial roles mostly.
exceptions: Managerial or Administrative roles often have different contracts.
Startups with specific employment agreements (though laws still apply).
rules.simple_explanation: If you are working beyond your shift hours, you are generally entitled to overtime pay or compensatory off, unless your contract specifically excludes it for your role.
rules.detailed_explanation: The Minimum Wages Act and Shops & Establishments Act mandate overtime payment at double the normal rate for work exceeding standard hours. 'Managerial' exemptions are often misused.
examples: Boss asks you to stay late every day without extra pay.
Working weekends typically requires a 'Comp-off' or overtime pay.
rules.what_to_say: I am happy to support the team, but these extra hours are significant. Can we discuss overtime pay or compensatory off for this time?

rules.summary: Employers cannot force you to resign.
conditions: Forced resignation is legally treated as illegal termination.
You have the right to refuse to sign.
exceptions: If you are being terminated for proven gross misconduct (with inquiry).
rules.simple_explanation: Your boss cannot force you to write a resignation letter. If they want to fire you, they must give you a termination letter, which usually requires severance or notice pay.
rules.detailed_explanation: Companies often force resignation to avoid paying retrenchment compensation or to hide firing statistics. This is illegal under the Industrial Disputes Act.
examples: HR calls you into a room and demands you sign a resignation letter immediately.
rules.what_to_say: I am not resigning. If the company wishes to terminate my employment, please provide a formal termination letter stating the reasons.

rules.summary: Employment bonds are only valid for training costs.
conditions: Employer must prove they spent money on your specific training.
Bond amount must be reasonable and proportionate to the loss.
exceptions: Generic 'onboarding' costs do not count.
Bonds cannot be used to force you to stay against your will (forced labor).
rules.simple_explanation: A bond is only valid if the company spent actual money on your specialized training. They cannot demand a huge random amount just for leaving.
rules.detailed_explanation: Section 27 of the Indian Contract Act voids agreements in restraint of trade. Courts only allow recovery of 'actual training expenses', not penalties.
examples: Company asks for â‚¹2 Lakhs for leaving, but gave no training.
rules.what_to_say: I am willing to reimburse the actual cost of training provided to me. Please share the breakdown of these specific expenses.

rules.summary: Employer cannot withhold your Experience Letter.
conditions: You have served the notice period or paid in lieu of it.
No pending dues from your side.
exceptions: If you absconded without notice.
rules.simple_explanation: If you have resigned properly and served your notice, the company must provide an Experience/Relieving letter. They cannot hold it hostage.
rules.detailed_explanation: Withholding service certificates restricts an employee's right to profession (Article 19(1)(g)). Courts have ruled that employers are duty-bound to issue these.
examples: HR says they won't give relieving letter until you sign a non-compete.
rules.what_to_say: I have completed my exit formalities. Withholding my experience letter is legally untenable. Please release it immediately.

rules.summary: Colleges cannot keep your original certificates.
conditions: UGC guidelines strictly prohibit withholding certificates.
Cannot be held as 'security' for fees.
exceptions: Brief verification during admission (must be returned immediately).
rules.simple_explanation: No college or university has the right to keep your original marksheets or degree certificates. They can only verify them and return them.
rules.detailed_explanation: The UGC Notification on Student Entitlements states that institutions cannot rob students of their credentials to force fee payment or prevent transfer.
examples: College refuses to return 10th/12th marksheets until full 4-year fee is paid.
rules.what_to_say: As per UGC guidelines, retaining original certificates is not permitted. Please verify them and return them to me today.

rules.summary: Colleges can bar you from exams for low attendance.
conditions: Attendance is below the mandatory limit (usually 75%).
University ordinances typically support this rule.
exceptions: Medical grounds usually allow for 10-15% relaxation.
Participation in sports/NCC/NSS.
rules.simple_explanation: Yes, colleges generally have the right to stop you from writing exams if your attendance is below 75%, unless you have a valid medical reason.
rules.detailed_explanation: Attendance rules are set by the University's statutory ordinances. Courts usually do not interfere unless the action is arbitrary or rules weren't published.
examples: You have 50% attendance and no medical certificate.
rules.what_to_say: I have valid medical reasons for my absence and can submit the necessary certificates for condonation of shortage.

rules.summary: Colleges must refund fees upon withdrawal.
conditions: Within 15 days of last admission date: 100% refund (minus small processing fee).
After 30 days: No refund usually mandated.
exceptions: Hostel fees might have different deduction rules.
rules.simple_explanation: If you withdraw your admission before the session starts or within a specific period, the college MUST refund your fees. They cannot keep the entire amount.
rules.detailed_explanation: UGC Fee Refund Guidelines mandate a tiered refund system (100%, 90%, 80%, etc.) based on when the withdrawal is made relative to the cutoff date.
examples: College says 'fees once paid is non-refundable' even if you leave in 2 days.
rules.what_to_say: As per UGC Fee Refund Guidelines, I am entitled to a refund since I am withdrawing within the stipulated permissible period.

rules.summary: Police cannot check your phone without a warrant.
conditions: Generally requires a warrant.
You are not under arrest for a serious crime.
exceptions: If you are arrested, they may seize it as evidence (procedure applies).
Emergency situations (rare).
rules.simple_explanation: Police cannot simply stop you and demand to see your WhatsApp or photos. That is a violation of privacy unless they have a warrant or you are being arrested.
rules.detailed_explanation: Privacy is a fundamental right. Random roadside checks of personal devices are not authorized under the CrPC without specific suspicion or orders.
examples: Traffic police asks to see your gallery or chats.
rules.what_to_say: I do not consent to a search of my private device without a warrant or legal notice.

rules.summary: Police must tell you the reason for detention.
conditions: They CAN detain you, but MUST inform you of the grounds immediately.
Must be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours.
exceptions: Preventive detention laws (strict procedures apply).
rules.simple_explanation: Police can detain you if they suspect a crime, BUT they must immediately tell you why. You have the right to ask 'Am I under arrest?'.
rules.detailed_explanation: Article 22 of the Constitution guarantees that no person shall be detained without being informed of the grounds for arrest.
examples: Police ask you to come to the station without saying why.
rules.what_to_say: Am I under arrest? If so, please inform me of the grounds. If not, am I free to go?

rules.summary: Women generally cannot be arrested after sunset.
conditions: Between 6 PM and 6 AM.
Unless there is a special order from a Magistrate.
exceptions: Serious crimes with Magistrate's permission (must be by female officer).
rules.simple_explanation: Women cannot be arrested or called to the police station between 6 PM and 6 AM. Questioning should technically happen at their residence.
rules.detailed_explanation: Section 46(4) of the CrPC provides special protection to women, prohibiting night arrest except in exceptional circumstances with judicial permission.
examples: Police try to take a woman to the station at 8 PM for questioning.
rules.what_to_say: As per the CrPC, women cannot be called to the station or arrested after sunset. Please come back with a female officer during the day.

rules.summary: You must show traffic documents to uniformed officers.
conditions: Officer must be in uniform.
You can show digital docs via DigiLocker (valid).
exceptions: If you do not have docs, you may be fined.
rules.simple_explanation: You are legally required to show your License, RC, and Insurance if a uniformed police officer asks. However, you can show them on the DigiLocker app instead of physical papers.
rules.detailed_explanation: Under the Motor Vehicles Act, a driver must produce documents upon demand by any police officer in uniform. Digital versions are valid under IT Act/MoRTH rules.
examples: Cop asks for license at a checkpost.
rules.what_to_say: I have my documents here (or on DigiLocker). I am happy to show them to you.

rules.summary: Traffic police cannot seize your vehicle keys.
exceptions: If you are trying to flee or the vehicle is being impounded for a crime.
rules.simple_explanation: A traffic policeman does not have the right to forcefully take your car or bike keys to stop you. This is illegal.
rules.detailed_explanation: No provision in the Motor Vehicles Act authorizes the seizure of keys. It is often considered harassment.
examples: Cop snatches bike keys at a signal.
rules.what_to_say: Please do not remove my keys. I am cooperating and not fleeing. You can note my details.

conditions: Lock-in clauses must not be 'one-sided' or 'unconscionable'.
Penalty should reflect actual loss.
exceptions: Commercial leases often have stricter valid lock-ins.
rules.simple_explanation: If a contract says you cannot leave for 3 years or must pay a huge fine, it might be unfair. Courts often strike down penalties that are not genuine estimates of loss.
rules.detailed_explanation: One-sided clauses where only the employee/tenant is bound are often considered 'unfair trade practices' or void under Contract Act principles.
examples: Gym membership says no refund and 1 year lock-in even if you move cities.
rules.what_to_say: This lock-in clause seems one-sided. I am willing to give reasonable notice, but a huge penalty is likely not enforceable.

rules.summary: Landlord must refund deposit within reasonable time.
conditions: Deductions must be for actual damage, not 'wear and tear'.
Refund usually due upon handing over keys.
exceptions: Unpaid rent can be deducted.
rules.simple_explanation: A landlord cannot keep your security deposit without a valid reason. They can deduct for broken items but not for painting or normal usage marks.
rules.detailed_explanation: Tenancy agreements and Model Tenancy guidelines allow deduction only for 'damages' beyond normal wear and tear. Painting charges are usually landlord's responsibility unless agreed otherwise.
examples: Landlord deducts full deposit for 'painting' after you leave.
rules.what_to_say: Please provide the bills for the damages you are claiming. Normal wear and tear is not valid for deduction.

rules.summary: Landlord cannot evict you without notice.
conditions: Usually requires 1 month notice (or as per agreement).
Cannot forcefully throw your things out.
exceptions: Court order for eviction.
rules.simple_explanation: Your landlord cannot tell you to leave 'today' or throw your belongings out. They must follow the legal process and give proper notice.
rules.detailed_explanation: Rent control laws and the Transfer of Property Act require valid notice for termination of tenancy. Forced eviction without due process is illegal.
examples: Landlord asks you to vacate in 24 hours.
rules.what_to_say: I am entitled to proper legal notice as per our agreement/law. Immediate eviction is illegal.
rules.source_category: Rent Control Act / Transfer of Property Act

rules.summary: No Refund policies are often illegal.
conditions: If service was deficient or product defective.
Absolute 'No Refund' boards are void.
exceptions: Perishable goods or custom-made items.
rules.simple_explanation: Shops cannot simply say 'No Exchange/No Refund'. If the product is defective, they MUST repair, replace, or refund it.
rules.detailed_explanation: Consumer Protection Act classes absolute restrictive trade practices as illegal. Consumers have a right to redressal for defective goods.
examples: Bought a shirt, zipper is broken, shop says 'No Refund'.
rules.what_to_say: As a consumer, I am entitled to a replacement or refund for a defective product. 'No Refund' policies do not override the law.
